tn.text: This marks the beginning of a new section of the book.
This refers to what David will say in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:23:01|23:2-7]].

tn.ref: the man who was highly honored, the one anointed by the God of Jacob
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the man whom the God of Jacob highly honored and anointed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: anointed by the God of Jacob
tn.text: Anointing was done by pouring oil on a person's head. This was done to choose who would serve God as king or priest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This is a person who writes psalms or songs.
by David

tn.ref: and his word was on my tongue
tn.text: Here "on my tongue" is a metonym for David speaking. AT: "he gave me a message to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This continues David's last words.

tn.ref: The God of Israel spoke, the Rock of Israel ... me
tn.text: Here the "God of Israel" is the same as the "Rock of Israel." The two phrases say essentially the same thing. David compares God to a rock to emphasize his power to protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The one who rules righteously over men, who rules in the fear of God
tn.text: These two sentences both say that the king will respect God and do what God wants him to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"respecting God"

tn.ref: He will be like the morning light ... sunshine after rain
tn.text: Here God is comparing the king to the morning light and sunshine after the rain. These are all ways of saying this king would be a delight to God and a blessing for the people. These two phrases have a similar meaning and are used for emphasis. AT: "He will be a delight to all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This continues David's last words.

tn.ref: Indeed, is my family not like this before God?
tn.text: Here David is saying that he agrees with God. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "My family is indeed like this before God!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
David acknowledges that God has made a covenant with him. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "He has indeed made ... way." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This means God's covenant is properly organized and will not change so David's family can trust it.

tn.ref: Does he not increase my salvation ... desire?
tn.text: David believes that God will always help him and cause him to prosper. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "He increases my salvation and gives me my every desire." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This concludes David's last words.

tn.ref: But the worthless will all be like thorns to be thrown away
tn.text: Here the wicked person is compared to useless thorns. This can be stated in active form. AT: "But the wicked person is worthless and dangerous like thorns we throw away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: because they cannot be gathered by one's hands
tn.text: "because no one can pick them up with his hands without the thorns hurting him"

tn.ref: They must be burned up where they lie
tn.text: "Where thorns are found, that is where they must be burned." This means God will destroy wicked people.

This is the name of a man. Other versions read Josheb Basshebeth, Jashobeam, Ishbaal, or Ishbosheth because various ancient copies have these variations. Translators may choose to say this in a footnote to their translation (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people group. AT: "son of Hachmon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"800" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This continues the list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This means that the army returned after Eleazar returned from battle. AT: "The Israeli army returned to the battle field after Eleazer had already won the battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"only to take what they wanted from the dead bodies of the enemies"
This continues the list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"a field where someone had planted lentils"
a flat seed, eaten like beans (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"the Israelite army ran away"
These are not the same three soldiers mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:23:08|23:8-12]].

"the 30" or "the thirty bravest Israelite soldiers." The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"cave near the town of Adullam." Adullam is near Bethlehem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a place. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:05:17|5:18]].
"in his protected place"

tn.ref: the Philistines had established at Bethlehem
tn.text: "some Philistines soldiers were controlling the village of Bethlehem"
"fought their way through the enemy army"

tn.ref: Should I drink the blood of men who have risked their lives?
tn.text: David compares the water to blood because the men risked their lives to bring the water to him. He uses a question to emphasize this. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Drinking this water would be like drinking the blood of those men who have risked their lives to bring it to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These are the names of men. Translate them as in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:02:18|2:18]].
This means Abishai was the leader of the three who went and got water for David.
"300 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: He was often mentioned along with the three soldiers
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "People often mentioned him when they spoke about the three bravest men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Was he not even more famous than the three?
tn.text: This question is used to emphasize how famous he was. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "He was even more famous than the three." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to Josheb Basshebeth, Eleazar, and Shammah. Abishai was not as famous as these soldiers.
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:08:15|8:18]].
This is the name of a man.
"did these mighty deeds"

tn.ref: he was named alongside the three mighty men
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people praise him like they praised the three mighty men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He was more highly regarded than the thirty soldiers in general, but he was not regarded quite as highly as the three most elite soldiers
tn.text: "He was more famous than the other 30 soldiers except for the three best soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This refers to Josheb Basshebeth, Eleazar, and Shammah.
a group of soldiers in charge of guarding David
This is a list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"The 30 very famous soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This continues the list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This continues the list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This concludes the list of David's greatest soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
seven in all** - "there were 37 total" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
